canonical_explanation.text: Plants make their own food through a process called photosynthesis. They use sunlight, water (from roots), and carbon dioxide (from air) along with chlorophyll (green pigment in leaves) to make food. During this process, plants release oxygen. Chlorophyll is the substance that gives leaves their green colour. Flowers are the reproductive parts of a plant. A flower has four main parts: sepals (protect the bud), petals (colourful, attract insects), stamens (male part with anther and filament), and pistil (female part with stigma, style, and ovary). Pollination is the transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma. Self-pollination happens within the same flower, while cross-pollination happens between two flowers, carried by agents like wind, water, insects, or birds. After pollination, the ovary develops into a fruit and the ovules become seeds. Seeds need to spread away from the parent plant to avoid overcrowding. This is called seed dispersal. Seeds can be dispersed by wind (dandelion, maple), water (coconut, lotus), animals (berries, mango), or explosion (balsam, pea pod).
rules: Photosynthesis: plants make food using sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide
Chlorophyll in leaves is green and helps in making food
Plants take in carbon dioxide and release oxygen
Flower parts: sepals, petals, stamens (male), pistil (female)
Pistil has stigma, style, and ovary
Pollination: transfer of pollen from anther to stigma
Agents of pollination: wind, water, insects, birds
After pollination, ovary becomes fruit, ovule becomes seed
Seed dispersal: by wind, water, animals, or explosion
Seed dispersal prevents overcrowding of plants

questions.question_text: What is the process by which plants make their own food called?
questions.explanation_correct: Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants make their own food using sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide. The word 'photo' means light and 'synthesis' means to make.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Digestion is breaking down food in the body, respiration is breathing, and pollination is transfer of pollen. The process by which plants make food using sunlight is called photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Which three things do plants need to make food?
questions.explanation_correct: Plants need sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to make food through photosynthesis. Water comes from the roots, carbon dioxide from the air, and sunlight provides the energy for the process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants do not use oxygen, sugar, or minerals directly to make food. The three key ingredients for photosynthesis are sunlight (energy source), water (from roots), and carbon dioxide (from air).

questions.question_text: What gives leaves their green colour?
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorophyll is the green pigment present in leaves. It gives leaves their green colour and plays a key role in photosynthesis by capturing sunlight to help make food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water, sunlight, and carbon dioxide are needed for photosynthesis, but they do not give the green colour. The green colour of leaves comes from a special substance called chlorophyll.

questions.question_text: Which gas do plants release during photosynthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: During photosynthesis, plants take in carbon dioxide and release oxygen. This oxygen is what we breathe in, which is why trees and plants are so important for all living things.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants take in carbon dioxide (not release it) during photosynthesis. They release oxygen, which is the gas that all animals and humans need to breathe.

questions.question_text: True or False: Plants can make food even without sunlight.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Sunlight is essential for photosynthesis. Without sunlight, plants cannot make food because sunlight provides the energy needed for the process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Plants must have sunlight to carry out photosynthesis. A plant kept in complete darkness will not be able to make food and will eventually die.

questions.question_text: Riya kept a green plant in a dark cupboard for many days. What will happen to the plant?

options.text: It will turn yellow and may die because it cannot make food without sunlight

questions.explanation_correct: Without sunlight, the plant cannot carry out photosynthesis and make food. The chlorophyll in the leaves will break down, turning the leaves yellow. Over time, the plant will weaken and may die.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A plant cannot survive without sunlight because it needs sunlight for photosynthesis. Without food production, the plant's leaves will turn yellow and the plant may eventually die.

questions.question_text: Why are plants called the 'food factories' of nature?

options.text: Because they are found in factories
Because they make their own food and also provide food for animals and humans
Because they store food in shops

questions.explanation_correct: Plants are called 'food factories' because they make their own food through photosynthesis and are the main source of food for animals and humans. Almost all food chains begin with plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants do not work in factories, eat other plants, or store food in shops. They are called food factories because they produce food using sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide, feeding all living things.

questions.question_text: Which part of the plant takes in carbon dioxide for photosynthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Leaves take in carbon dioxide from the air through tiny pores. The leaves are also where photosynthesis mainly takes place because they contain chlorophyll and have a large surface area to catch sunlight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Roots absorb water from the soil, and the stem carries water and food. It is the leaves that take in carbon dioxide through tiny pores and carry out photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: During photosynthesis, plants take in ________ and release ________.
questions.explanation_correct: During photosynthesis, plants take in carbon dioxide (CO2) from the air and release oxygen (O2). This is very important because oxygen is what all animals and humans need to breathe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants do not take in oxygen during photosynthesis; they release it. The correct answer is that plants take in carbon dioxide and release oxygen during photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Which part of a flower protects it when it is a bud?
questions.explanation_correct: Sepals are the green leaf-like parts at the base of a flower. When the flower is still a bud, the sepals cover and protect it. Once the flower opens, the sepals can be seen underneath the petals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petals are the colourful parts that attract insects, stamens are the male parts, and the pistil is the female part. Sepals are the green parts that protect the flower bud.

questions.question_text: What is the function of petals in a flower?

options.text: To attract insects and birds with their bright colours

questions.explanation_correct: Petals are the colourful and sometimes fragrant parts of a flower. Their bright colours and sweet scent attract insects and birds, which help in pollination by carrying pollen from one flower to another.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seeds are made in the ovary, water is absorbed by roots, and food is made in leaves. Petals attract insects and birds with their bright colours and fragrance to help with pollination.

questions.question_text: Which is the male part of a flower?
questions.explanation_correct: The stamen is the male part of a flower. It consists of the anther (which produces pollen grains) and the filament (which holds up the anther). A flower usually has several stamens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pistil is the female part, sepals protect the bud, and petals attract pollinators. The stamen is the male reproductive part of the flower.

questions.question_text: The pistil has three parts. Which of these is NOT a part of the pistil?
questions.explanation_correct: The anther is NOT a part of the pistil. The anther belongs to the stamen (male part). The pistil (female part) has three parts: stigma (sticky top), style (tube in the middle), and ovary (bottom, contains ovules).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stigma, style, and ovary are all parts of the pistil. The anther is part of the stamen (male part), not the pistil (female part). The anther produces pollen grains.

questions.question_text: Where in the flower are pollen grains made?
questions.explanation_correct: Pollen grains are made in the anther, which is the top part of the stamen. The anther is like a small bag that holds the pollen. When the anther opens, pollen grains are released.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The stigma receives pollen, the ovary contains ovules, and petals attract pollinators. Pollen grains are made only in the anther, which is part of the stamen (male part).

questions.question_text:
Match the flower parts with their functions:
1. Sepals - (a) Makes pollen
2. Petals - (b) Contains ovules
3. Anther - (c) Protects the bud
4. Ovary - (d) Attracts insects

Choose the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Sepals protect the bud (1-c), Petals attract insects with colour (2-d), Anther makes pollen (3-a), and Ovary contains ovules that become seeds (4-b).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Sepals = protection, Petals = attraction, Anther = pollen production, Ovary = contains ovules. The correct matching is 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b.

questions.question_text: The ________ is the female part of the flower that contains the stigma, style, and ovary.
questions.explanation_correct: The pistil is the female part of the flower. It has three parts: the stigma at the top (sticky, receives pollen), the style in the middle (tube), and the ovary at the bottom (contains ovules).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The stamen is the male part. Sepals protect the bud. Petals are colourful parts. The pistil is the female part of the flower with stigma, style, and ovary.

questions.question_text: What is pollination?

options.text: The growth of a seed into a plant
The transfer of pollen from the anther to the stigma
The making of food by leaves

questions.explanation_correct: Pollination is the transfer of pollen grains from the anther (male part) to the stigma (female part) of a flower. This is an important step that must happen before a plant can make seeds and fruits.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seed growth is germination, seed spreading is dispersal, and food making is photosynthesis. Pollination specifically means the transfer of pollen from the anther to the stigma.

questions.question_text: When pollen is transferred within the same flower, it is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Self-pollination occurs when pollen from the anther falls on the stigma of the same flower. This can happen without the help of wind or insects since both parts are in the same flower.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross-pollination involves two different flowers, seed dispersal is spreading of seeds, and germination is seed growth. When pollen stays within the same flower, it is self-pollination.

questions.question_text: Which of these is an agent of pollination?
questions.explanation_correct: Bees are one of the most important agents of pollination. When bees visit flowers to collect nectar, pollen sticks to their body and gets carried to other flowers, helping in cross-pollination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Roots, leaves, and soil are not agents of pollination. Agents of pollination are things that carry pollen from one flower to another, such as bees, butterflies, birds, wind, and water.

questions.question_text: Why do flowers have bright colours and sweet nectar?

options.text: To attract insects and birds for pollination

questions.explanation_correct: Flowers have bright colours and sweet nectar to attract insects like bees and butterflies, and birds like hummingbirds. These visitors carry pollen from flower to flower, helping in cross-pollination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While flowers are indeed pretty, their colours and nectar serve an important purpose in nature: attracting pollinators like insects and birds who help transfer pollen between flowers.

questions.question_text: Grass flowers are not colourful and have no nectar. How are they most likely pollinated?
questions.explanation_correct: Grass flowers do not need bright colours or nectar because they are pollinated by wind, not insects. Wind-pollinated flowers produce lots of light pollen that can be carried easily by the breeze.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Flowers that are pollinated by insects and birds are usually colourful and have nectar. Since grass flowers have neither, they are pollinated by wind, which does not need colours or nectar to carry pollen.

questions.question_text: True or False: Cross-pollination happens when pollen goes from one flower to another flower.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Cross-pollination occurs when pollen is transferred from the anther of one flower to the stigma of another flower. This is usually done by agents like wind, insects, birds, or water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is actually true. Cross-pollination involves two different flowers, while self-pollination happens within the same flower.

questions.question_text: Which of these is NOT an agent of pollination?
questions.explanation_correct: Soil is NOT an agent of pollination. The agents of pollination are wind, water, insects (like bees and butterflies), and birds. Soil helps plants grow by providing nutrients and support, but it does not carry pollen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wind, bees, and water can all carry pollen from one flower to another. Soil is the only option that is not an agent of pollination. It helps plants grow but does not transfer pollen.

questions.question_text: What happens after pollination in a flower?

options.text: The ovary develops into a fruit and ovules become seeds

questions.explanation_correct: After pollination, the ovary of the flower develops into a fruit, and the ovules inside the ovary become seeds. The other parts of the flower like petals and stamens usually dry up and fall off.
questions.explanation_incorrect: After pollination, the flower does not grow bigger or produce more pollen. Instead, the ovary becomes a fruit and the ovules become seeds. This is how plants reproduce.

questions.question_text: What is seed dispersal?

options.text: The spreading of seeds away from the parent plant

questions.explanation_correct: Seed dispersal is the spreading or scattering of seeds away from the parent plant. This happens naturally through wind, water, animals, or explosion, and helps seeds find new places to grow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Planting, watering, and eating seeds are human activities. Seed dispersal is the natural process of seeds being carried away from the parent plant to new locations.

questions.question_text: Dandelion seeds are light and have fluffy parachutes. How are they dispersed?
questions.explanation_correct: Dandelion seeds are very light and have fluffy, parachute-like structures. When the wind blows, these seeds float through the air and land in new places far from the parent plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seeds that are light and have fluffy parts are designed for wind dispersal. Dandelion seeds use their parachute-like structure to fly long distances with the wind.

questions.question_text: Coconut seeds float on water. How are they dispersed?
questions.explanation_correct: Coconuts are dispersed by water. The coconut has a hard shell and a fibrous outer covering that helps it float. Ocean currents can carry coconuts to new beaches where they can grow into new palm trees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coconuts are too heavy for wind dispersal. Their ability to float on water means they are dispersed by water currents. Coconut palms are often found near coastlines for this reason.

questions.question_text: Some seeds have hooks that stick to animal fur. This is an example of seed dispersal by:
questions.explanation_correct: Seeds with hooks or spines, like those of xanthium (gokhru), stick to the fur of animals or clothes of people. The animals carry these seeds to new places, which is dispersal by animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seeds with hooks are not carried by wind, water, or explosion. They stick to animal fur or human clothes and get carried to new locations, making this dispersal by animals.

questions.question_text: The balsam plant's seed pods burst open when ripe and throw seeds away. This is dispersal by:
questions.explanation_correct: The balsam plant disperses seeds by explosion. When the seed pods are ripe, they burst open suddenly and scatter the seeds in different directions. Pea pods also disperse seeds in a similar way.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When seed pods burst open and throw seeds, it is called dispersal by explosion (or bursting). This is different from wind, water, or animal dispersal. Balsam and pea plants use this method.

questions.question_text: Why is seed dispersal important for plants?

options.text: It helps seeds get more sunlight
It prevents overcrowding and helps plants grow in new places
It makes the parent plant stronger

questions.explanation_correct: Seed dispersal is important because it prevents overcrowding near the parent plant. If all seeds fell in one place, they would compete for sunlight, water, and space. Dispersal helps plants spread to new areas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seed dispersal does not affect taste or make the parent plant stronger. Its main benefit is preventing overcrowding by spreading seeds to new locations where they can get enough sunlight, water, and space to grow.

questions.question_text:
Match the seed with its method of dispersal:
1. Dandelion - (a) Water
2. Coconut - (b) Explosion
3. Balsam - (c) Wind
4. Xanthium - (d) Animals

Choose the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Dandelion seeds are dispersed by wind (1-c) because they are light with fluffy parachutes. Coconut by water (2-a) because it floats. Balsam by explosion (3-b) because pods burst open. Xanthium by animals (4-d) because it has hooks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct matching is: Dandelion = wind (light, fluffy), Coconut = water (floats), Balsam = explosion (pods burst), Xanthium = animals (hooks stick to fur).

questions.question_text: True or False: Birds help in seed dispersal when they eat fruits and drop seeds in new places.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. When birds eat fruits like berries, they may drop seeds while eating or the seeds pass through their body and come out as droppings in different places. This is an important way seeds are dispersed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Birds are important agents of seed dispersal. They eat fruits, fly to different places, and the seeds end up in new locations far from the parent plant.

questions.question_text: If there were no green plants on Earth, what would happen?

options.text: There would be less oxygen and no food for animals
The earth would become very hot

questions.explanation_correct: Without green plants, there would be no photosynthesis. This means no oxygen would be produced for animals and humans to breathe, and no food would be made since plants are at the bottom of all food chains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Green plants are essential for life. They produce the oxygen we breathe and are the base of all food chains. Without them, there would be no oxygen and no food for animals and humans.

questions.question_text: The sticky part at the top of the pistil that receives pollen is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The stigma is the sticky top of the pistil. It is sticky so that pollen grains can stick to it when they land on it during pollination. Below the stigma is the style, and at the bottom is the ovary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ovary is at the bottom of the pistil, the style is the tube in the middle, and the anther is part of the stamen. The stigma is the sticky top of the pistil that receives pollen.

questions.question_text: Which statement about self-pollination and cross-pollination is CORRECT?

options.text: Cross-pollination happens within the same flower
Cross-pollination needs agents like wind, insects, or birds

questions.explanation_correct: Cross-pollination requires agents to carry pollen from one flower to another. These agents include wind, water, insects (bees, butterflies), and birds. Without these agents, cross-pollination cannot happen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Self-pollination does not need insects (it happens within the same flower). Cross-pollination happens between two different flowers, not the same one. The correct statement is that cross-pollination needs agents like wind, insects, or birds.

questions.question_text: The green pigment in leaves that helps plants make food is called ________.
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorophyll is the green pigment found in leaves. It captures sunlight, which provides energy for the plant to make food through photosynthesis. This is why most leaves are green in colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nectar is the sweet liquid in flowers, pollen is the powder from anthers, and starch is a type of food. The green pigment in leaves is called chlorophyll.

questions.question_text: After pollination, which part of the flower becomes the fruit?
questions.explanation_correct: After pollination, the ovary of the flower develops into the fruit. The ovules inside the ovary become the seeds. So every fruit was once the ovary of a flower!
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petals, sepals, and anthers do not become fruits. It is the ovary that develops into a fruit after pollination, and the ovules inside become seeds.

questions.question_text: A squirrel eats a mango and drops the seed far from the mango tree. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: When a squirrel eats a mango and drops the seed far from the tree, it is seed dispersal by animals. Many animals eat fruits and carry seeds to new locations, helping plants spread.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A squirrel carrying and dropping a mango seed is an example of animal-aided seed dispersal. Wind, water, and explosion are not involved when animals eat fruits and scatter the seeds.

questions.question_text: Which part of the plant absorbs water from the soil for photosynthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Roots absorb water and minerals from the soil. This water is then transported through the stem to the leaves, where it is used in photosynthesis along with carbon dioxide and sunlight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leaves carry out photosynthesis but do not absorb water from soil. Flowers help in reproduction. The stem carries water upward. It is the roots that absorb water from the soil.

questions.question_text: A farmer notices many bees visiting his mustard field. How will this help his crop?

options.text: Bees will eat the pests on the plants
Bees will help in pollination so more seeds and fruits will form
Bees will make the flowers more colourful

questions.explanation_correct: Bees help in cross-pollination by carrying pollen from one flower to another as they collect nectar. More pollination means more seeds and fruits will form, which is great for the farmer's mustard crop.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bees do not eat pests, water plants, or change flower colour. Their main benefit to crops is pollination - carrying pollen between flowers, which leads to better seed and fruit production.

questions.question_text: True or False: The filament is the part of the stamen that holds up the anther.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The stamen has two parts: the anther (which makes pollen) and the filament (the thin stalk that holds up the anther). The filament supports the anther so pollen can be easily released.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The filament is indeed the thin stalk that supports and holds up the anther in the stamen.

questions.question_text: Which feature of a seed helps it disperse by wind?

options.text: Being light with wings or fluffy parts
Being able to float on water

questions.explanation_correct: Seeds dispersed by wind are light and have special features like wings (maple seeds), fluffy parachutes (dandelion), or thin flat shapes. These features help them float and travel in the air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heavy seeds cannot be carried by wind. Hooks help in animal dispersal, and floating helps in water dispersal. For wind dispersal, seeds need to be light with wings or fluffy structures.

questions.question_text: Complete the statement: In photosynthesis, sunlight + water + carbon dioxide = ________ + oxygen.
questions.explanation_correct: In photosynthesis, plants use sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to make food in the form of sugar or starch, and release oxygen. This food is stored in leaves, fruits, roots, and other plant parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants do not make proteins, fats, or minerals through photosynthesis directly. Photosynthesis produces food in the form of sugar/starch and releases oxygen as a byproduct.

questions.question_text: How many main parts does a flower have?
questions.explanation_correct: A flower has four main parts: sepals (protect the bud), petals (attract pollinators), stamens (male part, makes pollen), and pistil (female part, contains ovary). Each part has an important role.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A complete flower has four main parts: sepals, petals, stamens, and pistil. Roots, stems, and leaves are parts of the plant, not specifically parts of the flower.

questions.question_text: A butterfly lands on a sunflower to drink nectar. Pollen sticks to its legs. When it flies to another sunflower, the pollen falls on the stigma. What just happened?
questions.explanation_correct: This is cross-pollination because pollen was transferred from one flower to a different flower with the help of a butterfly. The butterfly acted as an agent of pollination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is not self-pollination (that happens within the same flower), seed dispersal (spreading of seeds), or germination (seed growth). Since pollen went from one flower to another flower, it is cross-pollination.

questions.question_text: Coconut seeds can travel long distances because they can ________ on water.
questions.explanation_correct: Coconuts have a fibrous outer covering that makes them float on water. This allows them to travel long distances across oceans and reach new shores where they can grow into new coconut trees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coconuts do not fly, sink, or roll across water. They float because of their light, fibrous outer covering, which allows water currents to carry them to distant places.

questions.question_text: Why do we say 'plants give us oxygen'?

options.text: Because plants breathe out oxygen at night
Because during photosynthesis, plants release oxygen into the air
Because plants are made of oxygen
Because plants store oxygen in their roots

questions.explanation_correct: During photosynthesis, plants take in carbon dioxide and release oxygen as a byproduct. This oxygen goes into the air, and all animals and humans breathe it in. This is why planting trees is so important.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants release oxygen during the process of photosynthesis (during the day when sunlight is available). They are not made of oxygen, nor do they store it in roots.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs is correct about flower parts?
questions.explanation_correct: The stamen (male part) = anther + filament. The pistil (female part) = stigma + style + ovary. These are two different reproductive parts of the flower.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The stamen is made of anther and filament (male part). The pistil is made of stigma, style, and ovary (female part). Do not mix up their components.

questions.question_text: If all seeds of a mango tree fell directly below the tree, what problem would arise?

options.text: The seeds would grow very fast
The young plants would compete for space, water, and sunlight
The seeds would be safer from animals

questions.explanation_correct: If all seeds fell in one place, the young plants would be overcrowded. They would compete with each other and the parent tree for water, sunlight, and space. Most of them would not survive. This is why seed dispersal is important.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seeds falling in one place does not make them grow faster, safer, or more productive. It causes overcrowding where plants compete for limited resources, and most seedlings would die.

questions.question_text: True or False: Pollination must happen before a plant can make seeds.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Pollination (transfer of pollen to the stigma) must happen before seeds can form. Without pollination, the ovules in the ovary cannot develop into seeds and the ovary cannot become a fruit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Pollination is an essential step in seed formation. Without pollen reaching the stigma, seeds cannot be formed.
